thread.title: Affinity Equity Partners seeks advisers for $NZ900m Tegel Foods sale
thread.title_full: Affinity Equity Partners seeks advisers for $NZ900m Tegel Foods sale | afr.com

author: afr.com
title: Affinity Equity Partners seeks advisers for $NZ900m Tegel Foods sale
text:
Affinity Equity Partners is considering a trade sale or initial public offering for New Zealand-based Tegel Foods. by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell Private equity firm Affinity Equity Partners contacted investment banks on Tuesday, seeking pitches for the sale of its New Zealand-based poultry producer Tegel Foods, sources told Street Talk.
Affinity is willing to consider both a trade sale and initial public offering for Tegel, which is expected to be worth about $NZ900 million, and would take pitches from about half a dozen investment banks in two weeks. It's understood two banks will be appointed.
Tegel is an integrated producer, processor, marketer and distributor of chicken and turkey products. It is majority-owned by Affinity with management holding less than 10 per cent.
Affinity bought the company from Pacific Equity Partners in 2011 for $NZ605 million, trumping bids from US fund Paine & Partners and Thailand's largest private company, The Charoen Pokphand Group. Macquarie Capital advised on this deal.
Affinity has made a few changes in the past three years. It divested Tegel's property assets in 2014 via a sale and leaseback and repaid a significant portion of the debt.
It's understood the pitch to new investors will be centred around the raft of international sales initiatives which have commenced under Affinity's ownership.
A sale would cap a busy period for the Asia-based Affinity, which has closed $3 billion of Australian deals in the past 12-months, including two proprietary transactions.
Affinity sold Primo Smallgoods to Brazilian meat processing giant JBS for a blockbuster $1.45 billion in November 2014. The deal with JBS, which is Australia's biggest meat packer, marketer and exporter and the world's largest processor of protein, valued Primo at eight times earnings and showed there was strong interest in local food producers, particularly from Asian and South American buyers.
 Potential buyers for Tegel include the usual global private equity suspects as well as Shuanghui Group, Shandong Minhe Animal Husbandry Co. Ltd., Charoen Pokphand and Brasil Foods.
Sources told Street Talk JBS would also take a look at Tegel given the strong relationship forged between Affinity and JBS during the Primo transaction, while Costa Group's recent raising showed there is demand for food-based industrial companies among listed equities investors.
Affinity bought a 35 per cent stake in Virgin Australia Holding's Velocity frequent flyer division for $336 million in October 2014, followed by the purchase of Nine Entertainment Co's Live division in April for about $640 million.
